Sure, here is a four-week training program that focuses on collar chokes, chokes, and strangles in Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu (BJJ):

1. Week 1: Fundamentals of collar chokes
* In this week, focus on learning the basics of collar chokes in BJJ.
* Practice executing common collar chokes, such as the collar-and-sleeve choke and the brabo choke.
* Work on improving your understanding of the mechanics and principles of collar chokes.
2. Week 2: Gi grips and control
* Spend this week focusing on improving your grip and control game in BJJ.
* Practice executing common grips, such as the lapel grip, sleeve grip, and collar-and-sleeve grip.
* Work on using the grips to control your opponent and set up collar chokes.
3. Week 3: Chokes and strangles
* In this week, focus on mastering various chokes and strangles in BJJ.
* Practice executing the chokes and strangles from a variety of positions, such as the guard, mount, and back control.
* Work on improving your defense against chokes and strangles and escaping from bad positions.
4. Week 4: Sparring and drilling
* Spend this week focusing on integrating the techniques you have learned into live sparring and drilling in BJJ.
* Practice executing the techniques against a resisting opponent in sparring.
* Work on drilling the techniques in a repetitive and controlled manner to improve muscle memory and efficiency.

Remember to always warm up before training, and to train with a partner if possible. It's also important to listen to your body and take regular breaks to avoid injury. Most importantly, have fun and enjoy the journey of learning BJJ!

* From bottom side control:
	+ Hip bump sweep: This sweep involves bumping your hips to create space and leverage, and then using your legs to push your opponent off balance and take the top position.
	+ Technical stand-up: This sweep involves using your hips and legs to push yourself up to your feet, and then using your arms to control your opponent's head and posture.
	+ Elevator sweep: This sweep involves using your legs to elevate your opponent off balance, and then using your hips and arms to take the top position.
* From closed guard:
	+ Triangle choke sweep: This sweep involves trapping one of your opponent's arms with your legs, and then using your other leg to trap their head and apply the triangle choke. As they attempt to defend the choke, you can use the leverage to sweep them and take the top position.
	+ Scissors sweep: This sweep involves trapping one of your opponent's legs with your legs, and then using your other leg to push their other leg away and take the top position.
	+ Hip bump sweep: This sweep involves bumping your hips to create space and leverage, and then using your legs to push your opponent off balance and take the top position.
* From half guard:
	+ Kimura sweep: This sweep involves trapping one of your opponent's arms with your legs, and then using your other leg to push their other leg away and take the top position. As you establish the top position, you can use your trapped arm to apply the kimura submission.
	+ Hook sweep: This sweep involves using your trapped leg to hook your opponent's leg, and then using your hips and arms to take the top position.
	+ Elevator sweep: This sweep involves using your legs to elevate your opponent off balance, and then using your hips and arms to take the top position.

Here are some good drills that you can perform at home to improve your skills in Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu (BJJ):

1. Shrimping: This drill involves practicing the shrimping movement, which is a fundamental movement used to escape from bad positions and maintain good posture. To do the shrimping drill, start by lying on your back and placing your hands under your hips. Then, use your hips and legs to push yourself backwards, while keeping your hands and shoulders in place. This will help you develop the flexibility and strength needed for effective shrimping.
2. Knee cutters: This drill involves practicing the knee cutter pass, which is a common guard pass used to take the top position. To do the knee cutter drill, start by sitting in the guard position and grabbing your opponent's ankles with your hands. Then, use your legs to control their legs and prevent them from escaping, and use your arms to push their knees towards the mat. This will help you develop the strength and control needed for effective knee cutter passes.
3. Bridge and roll: This drill involves practicing the bridge and roll movement, which is used to escape from bad positions and maintain good posture. To do the bridge and roll drill, start by lying on your back and placing your hands under your hips. Then, use your hips and legs to push yourself upwards into a bridge position, while keeping your hands and shoulders in place. From the bridge position, roll over onto your side and repeat the movement. This will help you develop the strength, control, and coordination needed for effective bridging and rolling.
4. Guard retention: This drill involves practicing the guard retention techniques, which are used to prevent your opponent from passing your guard and taking the top position. To do the guard retention drill, start by sitting in the guard position and grabbing your opponent's ankles with your hands. Then, use your legs to control their legs and prevent them from escaping, and use your arms to push their knees towards the mat. This will help you develop the strength and control needed for effective guard retention.

Remember to always warm up before training, and to listen to your body and take regular breaks to avoid injury. Also, be sure to continue learning and improving your skills and techniques in BJJ, and enjoy the journey of growth and self-improvement.

A gramby roll is a technique in Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu (BJJ) that involves using a rolling motion to escape from the bottom side control position. The gramby roll is named after Marcelo Garcia, who is a Brazilian BJJ practitioner and instructor known for his effective use of the technique.

To execute the gramby roll, you start by lying on your back with your opponent in the side control position on top of you. Then, you use your hips and legs to create space and leverage, and roll your body over onto your side. As you roll, you can use your arms to control your opponent's head and posture, and to prevent them from following you and re-establishing the side control position.

The gramby roll is an effective technique for escaping from the bottom side control position and taking the top position. It requires good coordination, control, and timing, and can be challenging to execute against a resisting opponent. However, with practice, you can develop the skills and confidence needed to successfully execute the gramby roll in BJJ.
